title: Problem Overview
content: Erdos Problem #602: Given family of countably infinite sets with finite (≠ 1) intersections, is there a 2-coloring avoiding monochromatic members? Status: OPEN.
mathContext: From [Er87], attributed to Komjath. Property B for infinite set families with intersection constraints.

title: Set Family
content: SetFamily(U, I) := I -> Set U. IsCountablyInfinite(S) := |S| = aleph0. AllCountablyInfinite: all members countably infinite.
mathContext: Family of sets indexed by I, each having cardinality aleph0 (countable infinity).

title: Intersection Conditions
content: HasFiniteIntersection: A_i ∩ A_j finite. IntersectionNotOne: |A_i ∩ A_j| ≠ 1. IsErdosFamily combines all conditions.
mathContext: The condition ≠ 1 is crucial. Single-element intersections enable counterexamples via constraint forcing.

title: 2-Colorings
content: TwoColoring(U) := U -> Bool. IsMonochromatic(S, c) := all elements same color. HasPropertyB: exists non-monochromatic coloring.
mathContext: Property B asks for existence of 2-coloring where no set is all one color.

title: Family Property B
content: IsValidColoring(A, c) := no A_i is monochromatic. FamilyHasPropertyB := exists valid coloring.
mathContext: Property B for families: find one coloring that works for ALL members simultaneously.

title: Main Conjecture
content: ErdosConjecture602 := every Erdos family has Property B. conjecture_equiv: equivalent to no counterexample exists.
mathContext: The open question: do the intersection conditions suffice to guarantee Property B?

title: Why Conditions Matter
content: |A_i| = aleph0: prevents finite pigeonhole. |A_i ∩ A_j| < aleph0: prevents forced monochromatic. ≠ 1: excludes constraint-forcing.
mathContext: Each condition rules out a class of counterexamples. The ≠ 1 condition is most subtle.

title: Komjáth's Problem
content: KomjathProblem := ErdosQuestion602. Originally posed by Komjáth.
mathContext: Erdos recorded this problem from Komjath in [Er87].

title: Special Cases
content: IsDisjointFamily: pairwise disjoint. IsAlmostDisjoint: finite intersections. Disjoint families trivially have Property B.
mathContext: Disjoint case is trivial. Almost disjoint with the ≠ 1 condition is the interesting case.

title: Counterexample Structure
content: Is2ChromaticForcing: every coloring has monochromatic member. counterexample_structure: equivalent to ¬ErdosConjecture602.
mathContext: A counterexample would be an Erdos family that forces some member to be monochromatic.

title: Problem Status
content: The problem is OPEN. Unknown whether every Erdos family has Property B or if counterexamples exist.
mathContext: Combines infinite set theory with combinatorial coloring. Neither answer has been established.
